questions.question: Which keyword is used to declare a constant in Java?
questions.explanation: The 'final' keyword is used to declare constants in Java. Once assigned, its value cannot be changed.

questions.question: What happens when float or double values are stored with more digits than the type can represent?
questions.option_a: a. The extra digits are rounded.
questions.option_b: b. The number is stored as an integer.
questions.option_c: c. The program throws an error.
questions.option_d: d. The extra digits are truncated.
questions.explanation: When float or double values exceed their precision, the extra digits are truncated, which may lead to small inaccuracies.

questions.question: Why is it not recommended to compare float or double values using '==' or '!=' relational operators?
questions.option_a: a. They throw a runtime error.
questions.option_b: b. Float and double values cannot be compared at all.
questions.option_c: c. Precision errors might cause inaccurate results.
questions.option_d: d. It is slower than using other operators.
questions.explanation: Due to truncation and rounding errors in float and double types, using '==' or '!=' can lead to inaccurate comparisons.

questions.question:
What is the purpose of the following line of code?

questions.option_b: b. To create a library file.
questions.option_c: c. To allow use of the Scanner class for user input.
questions.option_d: d. To save user input in a file.
